Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Infrastructure for Collaborative Faculty Textbook Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop infrastructure useful for sharing domain-specific course materials with collaborating Computer Science faculty sharing expertise in a particular domain. The centerpiece of the infrastructure is a free online-textbook; however the infrastructure also includes a membership-controlled area for course materials including projects, homeworks, experience reports, video lectures,
and slides.
This project will advance the state of the art for two relevant Computer Science textbooks, Operating Systems and Introduction to Performance. This content will serve as test material for a more general infrastructure to be developed for the purpose of developing Collaborative Faculty Textbook Communities. They key idea is to use the infrastructure to encourage and ease faculty contribution to, and adoption of, free online textbooks for their courses. The novel aspect is to focus on what the best infrastructure would be for a community of faculty, encouraging the longer-term maintenance and updating of the relevant course materials, and also encourage the participation of faculty with a high level of expertise and limited time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our work has been focused on the construction of free, online textbooks. To understand how to spread quality education materials in the best possible way, we utilize our own textbook, "Operating Systems: Three Easy Pieces" (http://www.ostep.org) as a case study. We have created materials within the book to teach students the basics of operating system design and implementation; we have also made such materials available for free, in a chapter by chapter basis, on the Internet. 

Our experiences reveal a number of critical aspects of free book construction. For example, one key is to make each chapter have a clearly delineated problem it is solving; if students can understand the problem, they can think of the solution. Second, each chapter should have a workable homework related to it; by doing work, rather than simply reading, better understanding is achieved. These, and related insights, make the book a successful educational tool.

We have also learned numerous lessons on how to make the book accessible to as many others as possible. One major problem is that many are not interested in an entire book but simply in smaller bits of information. Thus, each chapter is individually downloadable. A second problem is discovery; how can one find the material? On this, google searches are critical, but also links from trusted sources such as wikipedia. Finally, we have worked with others to translate the book into other languages; currently, a Korean edition is available, and a Chinese one will soon be.

We also make all of our book creation pipeline available to others (on demand); thus, we believe not only will our book lead the way on this cause, but also others will join towards a future where all college-level CS educational materials are available for free to all who seek out said knowledge.
